ratings.comment: A bright star in the statistics department. I had prior statistics knowledge before the class so account for that with the difficulty score, but she was a great teacher nonetheless. She covered and reviewed concepts well, and the homework questions were very similar to lecture problems. Exams were fairly easy and the project was not that difficult.

Most of the HW is completion-graded, and discussions are free points, so the class isn't very challenging, especially with prior stats or CS experience. No attendance means that lectures aren't super beneficial if you go through handouts on your own, but she explained concepts well. Exams were very short and usually easier than the homework.

Miranda definitely cares about her students but the lectures were often difficult to understand and so you kind of end up teaching yourself. She makes herself very accessible but isn't often super helpful so if you do take this class go to the Stats Help Desk. Lots of homework that's time consuming but tests aren't super difficult.

The expectations for prior knowledge in this class were not clear. This is an intro stats class but, you will likely struggle if you have no previous stats experience (as I didn't have any). This class uses R coding, which makes tests confusing. Not an easy/fun class. Only saving grace is that there is a generous curve and you get note sheets.

Pros: super generous with extensions due to mental health or illness, available to answer questions, records lectures
Cons: unengaging lectures, homework due Friday nights, homework takes a long time to complete

While lectures were boring, there isn't much you can do for a stats class. Miranda was very available outside of class and provided very in-depth online notes which were a lifesaver. This class is fine if you have taken a prior stats class but could be pretty difficult if you haven't. Homework takes a long time but you get note sheets on exams.

Miranda was a pretty good professor overall. Lectures can definitely be boring, but there's only so much you can do for a statistics course. Exams make up the majority of your grade and there are only 3 of them including the final. She was always available outside of class.

This class is tough if you haven't taken an intro stats course before (like stats 301/AP stats). If you're coming in w/ no stats knowledge, be careful. The order that we learn stuff doesn't really make sense until after you learn everything. 
Pros: lectures are recorded/no mandatory lecture & discussion. 
Cons:entire grade depends on hw and exams.

Miranda. Rintoul. An angel sent by the heavens to grace the UW Madison Statistics Department. Although many say negative things about her, I for one stand up in her defense. While she may have her days of confusion, overall, she is an amazing person and lecturer. #stopmirandahate

Professor Rintoul goes out of her way to make sure students pass her class! Lectures are recorded and posted on Canvas, so attendance isn't even required. The quizzes exams were much easier than the homework. Some information is conveyed in a counterintuitive way, but Professor Rintoul is happy to answer any questions

If I ever created a burn book, Miranda would be the front page. She seems to like her students, but behind the scenes, she's grinning ear to ear knowing she has the most confusing homework due Friday night. She loves to gaslight u into thinking it's easy & she's open to questions through piazza. But she will just lead u to a slide that says nothing

One of the worse if not the worst professor to text you in math. I feel bad for my high school  stats teacher cuz she taught me better and probably gets paid a fourth of Miranda's salary. UW Madison really needs to up their standards.

Miranda is very nice but that's it. She cannot teach or answer questions without confusing.  Her weekly assignments are due Friday night and crazy hard (expect 2+ hours to do it). Her test only have 4 long questions so if you don't know one question you automatically get 80-85%. So unless you can teach yourself this class will not be an easy.

She is a very nice person and is understanding in cases of extensions and needing help. That's all the good things I have to say. She is not a good lecturer. She just reads of slides with a wall of text and clicks through them way to fast. You're legitimately better off just copying down the lecture slides that she posts than watching the lectures.

I'm sure that Miranda is a lovely person outside of class. However, she treated lectures like checklists. Miranda's slides were essentially scripts and it seemed like we were ment to memorize everything she said as soon as it came out of her mouth. Homework was extremely difficult and due at strange times. Awful introduction to statistics.

Miranda is an average lecturer and clearly is passionate about seeing her student succeed. Also records lectures and posts lecture notes. The exams make up majority of the final grade, but the main problem was that each exam was pretty short (4-6 questions with 2-3 parts), therefore your grade was dictated by a small scope of questions

This class is really hard. Miranda pretty much just reads the lecture slides without much explanation- so get ready to teach yourself all of the material. What is expected on exams is not clear and homework is much harder than exams. Don't expect much help on homework- she is not very good at answering questions.

Miranda clearly cares about her students which is refreshing. She hosts reviews before every exam and brings cookies ect. and also walks around during lectures to help any student with calculations. However, she cannot teach. What she discusses in lecture seems easy in theory, and then the weekly homework and quiz are super difficult.

Tests are no longer online, however you have a whole piece of paper as a notecard. Lecture recorded. Miranda is helpful when approached with a question. The tests and homework can be difficult and at times feel foreign because most of class is spent being taught how to use R to code for the answer and then everything is done short hand for exams

Terrible professor. Made the tests extremely different from any course content you learned and made you use RStudio in bizarre ways for tests. Content was very boring and was taught with no enthusiasm so it was even more boring. Good thing about the class is that all exams were online and open-note.

Prof. Rintoul cares for her lectures deeply, and shows this by walking around the room for each in-class example. She explains concepts in a bite-sized and down-to-earth manner that many other professors simply cannot. The final (30%) was exceedingly difficult, and relied on knowledge loosely dispensed in discussion, but was curved to an 80% avg.

Miranda was a good lecturer and went into the theory of what was being covered. Homework was difficult but doable. Planned on giving a 5, but after the final, feel differently about the class. Exam was so difficult to the point that no student I have talked to knew how to start more than 3/7 problems. Spent 13 hours on the final, likely failed.

Miranda teaches all the theory very well in lecture, but then she gives these super hard word problems for homework and tests that I struggled a lot with, and few of which I can remember covering in class. This is fine on homework because of piazza, but for tests I just feel super lost and like I'm gonna fail.

As a teacher, Ms. Rintoul is very good. She's great at explaining things and she's very understanding. The tests are all online including the final and it is open book, however, the tests are still challenging. I dislike the course itself, but really like Ms. Rintoul. If you take Stats 371, hope you have her.

she makes the content in lectures seem so easy and then proceeds to give the most impossible homework and exams. they are open note but your notes dont help because they cover the info in the most simple way. I had her for 309 but that wasnt an option

Prof. Rintoul's recorded lectures were all extremely boring/monotone &difficult to get through, even at 2x speed. Material found within exams wasn't really covered well by lectures, & all assignments were incredibly difficult. She was very understanding when it came to extensions or rescheduling exams, but overall would not take from her again.

Took over our lecture as our prof was ill. Gave concrete exams of R code, explained further when asked to, and seemed kind. Sometimes the lecture slides were a little difficult to understand but it was doable. Did a review session before the exams too which were extremely helpful.

Miranda is a nice person, but not a good lecturer. Grade is mainly based on exams and the exams are nothing like the homework or quizzes. She did not provide us with any insight on where we would stand in the class until the final grades were posted. As long as you try to do better than the average on the exams, you should be fine.
Could not hear her over her annoyingly loud computer!!!!

You can tell that Miranda really cares about her students and wants them to learn, but sometimes has trouble dumbing down complex topics in a way non-stats students can understand. The tests are far harder than the homework, which makes it difficult to study for. To succeed, just make sure you stay on track with the class and homework.

Stats 371 is the worst class ever so I don't know how much of it can be blamed on Miranda. It's all coding with R, which I feel isn't known until you start the class. The exams are incredibly difficult and homework is really long. She says 'umm' every 5 seconds and I feel she isn't good at making it easy for people who have never taken a stats.

Class lectures were very difficult to follow and stay engaged with. She read off of her slides and the lecture content was much more simplified than the weekly homework and quiz.  I would go to every lecture and office hours and would always spend hours struggling to complete the homework, which is graded harshly on accuracy.

One of my favorite professors that I've had at UW. The class is challenging but if you attend lecture she lays everything out very clearly and in a well structured way. It is important to stay on top of this material from the start but if you do it will all make sense. Great experience. Would shake her hand if I could. Miranda has changed my life.

Cares a lot about students and checks in during lecture to make sure you understand the content. Not too hard to get an A if you attend lectures and discussions. Came in with 0 stats knowledge and managed to get an A.

Her lectures are practically useless and incredibly hard to get through as she will say Ummmmm or Uhhhhh multiple times a sentence when she is literally only reading off of the lecture slides. Aside from that the class isn't too miserably hard if you do the work but it is very easy to get behind.

Rintoul's lectures are hard to get through, she's not good at explaining things and just restates the words on the text-heavy slides in a slightly different way. Above all, she says "Ummm" every 10 seconds, which may not be important to many, but once you notice it, it is incredibly distracting. Class content is generic stats, just presented poorly
